text: I have a weird issue - i havent been running julia (well not since last night) but my mac seems to sometimes rather large memory usage from julia, considering julia isnt even running. any idea why this might be happening?

elements.text: I have a weird issue - i havent been running julia (well not since last night) but my mac seems to sometimes rather large memory usage from julia, considering julia isnt even running. any idea why this might be happening?

text: Hey <@U01A38DLY8N>, Thanks for asking this question. Is it okay if we cross post this to Discourse for further visibility and in case someone has the same question in the future? If so, please react with :bridge: on the original message you sent above above ^ (not this threaded reply). Note that only reactions from the posts author will trigger a re-post. Thank you for being here!

Hey <@U01A38DLY8N>! Thanks for asking this question. It has been cross posted to discourse here: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/i-have-a-weird-issue-i-havent-been-running-julia-well-not-since-last-night-but>. Please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benfit as well.

text: shouldn't be - have you restarted your device since you last used it?

elements.text: shouldn't be - have you restarted your device since you last used it?

text: I also noticed it this week. I could not pin point it because at some point that day I had used julia master version, 1.5.1 and also had a detached jupyter notebook. All of them were officially closed but I still saw several julia processes taking up like 1.5 GB of RAM. Interested in seeing what answers you get. I am using BigSur, by the way. My thought was that I had not killed correctly the jupyter kernels but I didn’t investigate further.

elements.text: I also noticed it this week. I could not pin point it because at some point that day I had used julia master version, 1.5.1 and also had a detached jupyter notebook. All of them were officially closed but I still saw several julia processes taking up like 1.5 GB of RAM. Interested in seeing what answers you get. I am using BigSur, by the way. My thought was that I had not killed correctly the jupyter kernels but I didn’t investigate further.

text: I often have several Julia processes running with no reason. They get left behind when I start a Julia notebook in Jupyter Lab, and then kill Jupyter from command line with Ctrl-C.

elements.text: I often have several Julia processes running with no reason. They get left behind when I start a Julia notebook in Jupyter Lab, and then kill Jupyter from command line with Ctrl-C.

text: There’s a message that says that Julia was restarted.

elements.text: There’s a message that says that Julia was restarted.

text: That sounds like unwanted behavior, no?

elements.text: That sounds like unwanted behavior, no?

text: Mmm, yes. I just kill them later.

elements.text: Mmm, yes. I just kill them later.

text: if you have a jupyter notebook open, it could very well be the kernel that's started when you open your browser

elements.text: if you have a jupyter notebook open, it could very well be the kernel that's started when you open your browser

text: :man-shrugging:
I prefer to use Pluto notebooks nowadays, makes it much more explicit when a process is kept running

elements.text: I prefer to use Pluto notebooks nowadays, makes it much more explicit when a process is kept running

text: Btw, the image didn’t transfer to Discourse.

elements.text: Btw, the image didn’t transfer to Discourse.

text: When Jupyter starts a Julia notebook it starts a kernel for it (a process). It’s easy for this to get left behind when you exit Jupyter. It’s easy to leave several behind.

elements.text: When Jupyter starts a Julia notebook it starts a kernel for it (a process). It’s easy for this to get left behind when you exit Jupyter. It’s easy to leave several behind.

text: I find Pluto hard to use because it feels cramped. Also I can’t open a separate console for the notebook kernel; I use those to install packages that are not already there.

elements.text: I find Pluto hard to use because it feels cramped. Also I can’t open a separate console for the notebook kernel; I use those to install packages that are not already there.

text: hm.. you could do `@spawn Pluto.run()` and keep the REPL that way, no?

elements.text: hm.. you could do
@spawn Pluto.run()
and keep the REPL that way, no?

text: I guess, but it’s not in the browser.

elements.text: I guess, but it’s not in the browser.

text: This is excellent! <https://jupyter-docker-stacks.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using/selecting.html#jupyter-datascience-notebook>

elements.text: This is excellent!

text:
It already has Julia 1.5.3. You can share the notebook from the laptop’s disk by using a command like this:
```docker run -p 8888:8888 -e JUPYTER_ENABLE_LAB=yes -v /Volumes/MyFiles/GitRepos/StatisticalMice/ProjectsPublic/Benchmarks:/home/jovyan jupyter/datascience-notebook:latest```
It starts the latest version of the datascience-notebook in jupyterlab and shares the directory `/Volumes/MyFiles/GitRepos/StatisticalMice/ProjectsPublic/Benchmarks` to the notebook, which then looks like it’s running locally. Except it doesn’t have any of my packages installed yet.
Then I just open this in the browser `<http://127.0.0.1:8888/lab?token=db17f5a8db314fb529c6b5c4a802d4c035c841877727a7ff>`

text: There’s some overhead. Now I just want to run it in AWS.

elements.text: There’s some overhead. Now I just want to run it in AWS.

text:
Having this at the start of the notebook fixes things:
```cd(@__DIR__)
using Pkg
Pkg.activate(".")
Pkg.instantiate()```

elements.text: Having this at the start of the notebook fixes things:

cd(@__DIR__)
using Pkg
Pkg.activate(".")
Pkg.instantiate()

text:
In my case it is possible that I had started my notebook with the `notebook(detached=true)`
which prevents it from being killed when exiting the julia session or the browser. Could it be that you are doing the same, Devansh? (see <https://julialang.github.io/IJulia.jl/stable/manual/running/#Running-the-IJulia-Notebook>)

elements.text: In my case it is possible that I had started my notebook with the
